(It was suggested that as much as 80% of their diet was acorn mush.)  And there was a good deal more on the huge variety plants used daily for eating, making rope, or thread, soap, etc. There are an impressive number of original artifacts (as well as a very knowledgeable and helpful docent).

I was surprised to learn that if you pounded small animals and birds lightly, you could break up their bones, and then eat the entire animal.  And of interest was how these, and every thing else, was cooked, in a culture with no pots..  (And, how they were caught.) 

Dress, culture, and ceremonies were also covered in some detail. 

My wife and I have visited quite a number of Indian museums and certainly some were bigger, but this particular museum, while small, was still excellent and a bargain for $5.00

This small but powerful museum is an historical representation of our early Native American societies in California. It has done a superb job of sharing an excellent historical preview of the lives of these tribal societies before, during, and after the fated invasion of the Spanish through an abundance of photographs, rich and authentic visuals and artifacts and documents.  It is a place of respect and humility. Children and adults should experience this educational awakening. This is a museum of reflection. I felt like a student again. This gem is awesome! This was our last day in Sacramento. Thank you!!!
Good for adults that appreciate indian information, but for children it might be a challenge

This is a very interesting place for anyone who wants to know about California's native people.  The Indian Museum is on the grounds of Sutter's Fort, and it's well worth a visit, especially if you are taking a look at the fort.
I loved this small museum. Although it is small it is worth a visit especially if you are visiting Sutters Fort at the same time.
This modest sized Museum is worthy of your thoughtful visit. The Native Ranger on duty brought several displays to life for us with his knowledge, insight and passion!

Wonderful museum with some really interesting exhibits on the native people of California, with great documentation and artifacts.  While the museum is somewhat small, its definitely worth spending an hour and is also located a couple minutes walk from the Sutter's Fort State Historic Site (located around the same park), which it complements well from a history perspective.  Definitely worth spending about an hour.

And not too much that would catch the eye for young kids.  The displays and the photographs are very complete, within their chosen, limited areas, and the descriptions are full of detail.  If you take the time to read them you will learn a lot.  I particularly enjoyed seeing samples of all the types of California acorns, their leaves, and how acorn mush was prepared, and its specialized utensils. (It was suggested that as much as 80% of their diet was acorn mush.)  And there was a good deal more on the huge variety plants used daily for eating, making rope, or thread, soap, etc. There are an impressive number of original artifacts (as well as a very knowledgeable and helpful docent).

I was surprised to learn that if you pounded small animals and birds lightly, you could break up their bones, and then eat the entire animal.  And of interest was how these, and every thing else, was cooked, in a culture with no pots..  (And, how they were caught.) 

Dress, culture, and ceremonies were also covered in some detail. 

My wife and I have visited quite a number of Indian museums and certainly some were bigger, but this particular museum, while small, was still excellent and a bargain for $5.00
Considering the name I thought the place would be more. Small museum, lots of baskets, few artifacts. Sorry guys, LA's Autry Museum has you beat by far!

This is the one place we highlighted as a "donʻt miss".  While there were interesting and well done exhibits, the extent of the offerings were very small.  As California and that area have many native tribes, we expected much more.

name: Governor's Mansion
reviews:
My mom and I parked nearby (Sunday parking on the street is free) and walked around the property. A Google search brings up an interesting article from 2015 about Governor Jerry Brown moving back into the mansion after restoration. And although not necessarily current, the CA Park Service has a good article which is basically the wording a tour guide used when the mansion was open for tours. 

The house is beautiful and worth a stop. It didn't appear anyone lived in the house, but a door to the carriage house was open so I'm not sure.

I love Home tours and this one is great, enhanced by the factual and anecdotal knowledge revealed by the State park Guides as you travel through the reflection of Leland Stanford embedded in his former home. A must see, and only a few blocks from the Capitol, an easy walk.
Enjoy a tour of the old Governor's Mansion. A lot of history in that old building. Well worth the time spent visiting. take the time while in Sacramento to check it out. You won't be sorry.

Although we live in Sacramento, we had never visited the Governor's mansion so thought it was about time.  They have tours on the hour and are open from 10am to 5pm, Wednesday through Sunday.  The tours last from 30 minutes to an hour, based on the size of the group and questions.  Our tour had more children which made it fun but probably on the longer side (almost an hour).  The mansion was built in 1877 as a private residence but since the early 1900s, it was home to 13 of California's Governors.  Since the late 60s, it has been run by the State Parks.  You can see items from various eras--furnishings, TVs, phones, appliances, photos, footed tubs, clothes, dishes, etc.  The tour was interesting and informative for only $5.  We were sad to hear that this was one of the sites that was slated for closure due to the Budget.  Let's hope that somehow they can save it.   

I posted some photos and review of my afternoon in Sacramento at: http://insightfultravel.wordpress.com/2012/02/19/sacramento-afternoon-in-february/

The Governor's Mansion is a walk back in time and California history. The guided tours can be fun or irritating depending on your guide. But no matter what it great viewing. I like to go in Dec. because  it is decorated for Christmas .

Although we live in Sacramento, we had never visited the Governor's mansion so thought it was about time.  They have tours on the hour and are open from 10am to 5pm, Wednesday through Sunday.  The tours last from 30 minutes to an hour, based on the size of the group and questions.  Our tour had more children which made it fun but probably on the longer side (almost an hour).  The mansion was built in 1877 as a private residence but since the early 1900s, it was home to 13 of California's Governors.  Since the late 60s, it has been run by the State Parks.  You can see items from various eras--furnishings, TVs, phones, appliances, photos, footed tubs, clothes, dishes, etc.  The tour was interesting and informative for only $5.  We were sad to hear that this was one of the sites that was slated for closure due to the Budget.  Let's hope that somehow they can save it.   

I posted some photos and review of my afternoon in Sacramento at: http://insightfultravel.wordpress.com/2012/02/19/sacramento-afternoon-in-february/
The neighborhood is run down and you are only able to view the outside of the home. I didn't feel very safe in the neighborhood on my own.

I knew the home is not available for tour but since it is just few blocks from the Capitol, I decided to stop by for some photos.  It was weekday afternoon and there were no signs by the home stating it is a Governor's mansion.  The home is fenced in on 2 sides but you can still see the front entrance from the street.  I did see the governor's family playing in the backyard while I was there while security details kept watch.

This perfect restoration  took years to complete but is exquisite .You don't get to go in because the Governor lives here but if if you are around on October 31st the Governor usually hands out candy in the evening

My hotel was near this mansion and I walked by it several times, Finally I looked it up online. Although Google says that Governor Brown moved back in after an extensive renovation, there were no signs indicating that this was the governor's house and no signs of security in place, so I wonder if that actually happened. All you can do is get a look from the street. Not worth a special trip.
Politics aside, this building is a nice building to look at for the outstanding architecture. I'm not downtown that often anymore, but its fun to walk around and look at the old building sometimes.

name: California Exposition & State Fair
reviews: Wouldn't have gone without a deal on Groupon. Parking on-site was way over priced!  Found free street parking instead.  Had been looking forward to live concerts, not so interested in cover bands.

On the Monorail you hear the narrator say that the State Fair is like Disneyland of the north. That WAS true.  It used to take THREE DAYS to see everything.  There were so many good attractions it felt like a Disney Theme Park.  But now, it takes less than one full day. 

This year the EXPO BUILDINGS have almost nothing to see at all.  There’s less art in the art buildings.  The Silent Disco doesn’t look like a Disco at all; just cheap projections on the walls. Building 5 was something about video games. And Building 8 was completely EMPTY. 

EXPO BUILDING EXHIBITS OF THE PAST USED TO FILL THE BUILDINGS WITH THINGS LIKE...
Actual Props from sci-fi movies and TV shows. 
Vintage Toys and Games. 
The Ice Man Exhibit.
Amusement Park History with items from old Amusement Parks.
People showing and talking about Eagles, Raccoons, Owls and more... 

There are less COUNTIES EXHIBITS than ever and none had the amazing waterfalls or mine tunnel walk through attraction, or buildings with animated figures in the windows.

The new WINE GARDENS are better than recent years. But years ago, the Gardens area was larger with several by landscapers hoping for a Blue Ribbon. 

No one in the INSECT PAVILION talking about the insects any more. I asked. 

Almost the entire FOOD FESTIVAL is beef or sweet stuff, and every item is very hard to find (even with the map).  One item could not be found at all.  Everyone we asked said that no one could find it. 

ATTRACTIONS IN THE 1990s WHERE THE KID’s CARNIVAL IS NOW

  I LOVE LUCY EXHIBIT
 I will never forget the replica of Lucy and Ricky's apartment and kitchen with actual props from the show.  

ACTUAL TRAIN RIDE 
There was a truly fun miniature train (brought to the Fair by a Train Club in Folsom) for adults and children of all ages to ride through a pretty large area for a few years.   

An OLD WEST TOWN for a few years.

OTHER ATTRACTIONS IN THE 1990s

BIG ANIMATRONIC DINOSAURS were in a huge tent like building between the Counties Building and the Jacuzzis every year.   

There was a SHARK TANK one year.

LIVE ENTERTAINMENT
Almost every one of the smaller stages used to have a big variety of really interesting, quality acts:  From Chinese Acrobats to International Folk Dancing to Karate Demonstrations and good bands.  But most of the stages now just have loud rock bands that are not very good.    And from what we saw this year, the Chinese Acrobat show is one guy spinning a plate. 

THE MIDWAY 
Until the late 1990s there was a quality carnival with an extremely tall FERRIS WHEEL at the west side of the carnival.  And at the entrance, there was a beautiful, large automated BAND ORGAN.  But in the late 1990s, something supposedly happened with the owner of that carnival, and the State Fair hired a new carnival owner who apparently does not own a large Ferris Wheel or Band Organ, but they do have a lot of duplicate rides.   

THE FIRST HDTV WAS AT THE STATE FAIR
 The State Fair used to feature innovations of technology.  They actually featured the very first HDTV in existence one year sponsored by KXTV with nature photography shot by KXTV photographers.  Everyone was blown away by the exhibit.  But the State Fair does not feature innovations at all any more. 

CONCLUSION
  I don't know what can be done about this, but I do hope that some day someone tries.  I want to feel like I'm actually in a Disney Theme Park again, when I visit the formerly Great California State Fair!!

The weather during the State Fair is always hot, but, its easy to cool off with the many water misters and going inside the exhibition halls. 
The live stock exhibitions seem to get smaller and smaller each year.  This year, there were only rabbits.  
Entertainment during the day was disgraceful.  With so much talent out there, they hire or get volunteers that are worst than karaoke. Better live entertainment happens at night.
Lots of rides and food.
But, food is very expensive.  The garlic fries were $8 for one potato worth of fries.
The BBQ tri-tip was even worst, $14 for a very small sandwich.  If beef was tender, that wouldn't have eased the pain of the price.   Best to go after a huge lunch.

Very fun, lots of ride for little kids and a wide selection for teens/adults. It feels as if the stands that sell goodies gets smaller and smaller every year. Parking is ridiculous & it’s HOT. But if the heat doesn’t bother you it’s fun to go try the food go on a few rides play a couple games and have fun

So Cal Expo has something for kids of all ages.

First of course is the fair. Best in the state. deep friend errrr everything, wine tasting, animals, good entertainment. carnies, horse racing and lots of those fun, throw your money away, noy a chance to win a dirty stuffed animal, challenge booths.

name: The B Street Theatre
reviews:
First, the "new" B Street Theatre is located in The Sofia Tsakapoulos Center for the Arts.  For many years, our favorite venues were (1 ) The Harris Center in Folsom, (2)  The Crest Theatre on K St., (3) Sacramento Community Center Theatre, and (4) Sacramento Memorial Auditorium. [It's not an accident that I left off the Golden 1 Center].
Upon the opening of The Sofia...this incredible venue immediately jumped to #1 and has remained so.  The Sofia is simply the best entertainment venue the area has to offer: the best seating, the best acoustics, one of a kind performances...and, an unsurpassed value.  Our seasonal subscription includes 7 plays + 5 concerts of our choosing.  The plays have all been wonderful and the concerts:  Wishbone Ash, Ray Charles Project, Albert Cummings, Rick Estrin and the Nightcats, Al Jardine....incredible.  Plus, the artists come out into the lobby and mingle freely with the guests.  If you are not a member:  SUBSCRIBE!  Here's a great reason:  top class entertainment and the per person subscriber cost (12 events) is $140.00!!!  No, that's not a mistake.  $11.66 per person...per event!!!  Unbeatable.

They kept the name but moved to Capital Ave and 28th Street.   New building for both the Theatre and Music Venue.  They have comedy shows also.  The bar in the lounge has a variety of drinks.  The seats are comfortable and the crowd is always friendly.  Get to the show early for the best seats.
The Sofia Tsakopoulos Center for the Arts, home of the B Street Theatre is at 2700 Capitol Avenue in Sacramento.  This new center has fabulous seating and is a huge plus to downtown Sacramento.

Plus, the artists come out into the lobby and mingle freely with the guests.  If you are not a member:  SUBSCRIBE!  Here's a great reason:  top class entertainment and the per person subscriber cost (12 events) is $140.00!!!  No, that's not a mistake.  $11.66 per person...per event!!!  Unbeatable.

They kept the name but moved to Capital Ave and 28th Street.   New building for both the Theatre and Music Venue.  They have comedy shows also.  The bar in the lounge has a variety of drinks.  The seats are comfortable and the crowd is always friendly.  Get to the show early for the best seats.

Just got out of the Forever Question, and once again truly believe that the B St Theatre is my favorite date night.
Sets, lighting and costumes were great, acting did not disappoint. You'll laugh and have a fantastic time with your sweetie!
Love this new venue.  Wonderful, live music,plays.The sound is amazing all seats are wonderful.  And remember to check out the bar for a glass of wine.

We have been supporters of B Street for many years. We loved the intimacy of the old theater. It was funky and fun. A very unique place.
We have gone to a few plays at the new one and while they were enjoyable the atmosphere was not.
The people working there were not friendly. The building too modern and cold.
We gave the rest of our tickets away and will not be renewing our membership.
Wish B st. would have taken notice of the beautiful New York Broadway theaters and not try to be so modern and tacky

name: California Musical Theatre
reviews: Easy parking (reserve on the website when you purchase your theater tickets!) All seats are good. We were row "O" and happy with sound and viewing. We saw Lin Manuel Miranda's 2008 hit "In the Heights." Fantastic. We might just consider season tickets for next year!

I love the layout of this Theater! The stage is in the center of the theater with seats all around. The seats don't go back too far so no one is far from the stage. My daughter loved The Wiz performance! The actors were really good and entertaining! We had a good time! The plus side of this being a smaller theater is that the lines for concession and restrooms don't get too long during intermission. We appreciated this after visiting larger theaters in the past and not having time during intermission to use the restroom. I will be checking their schedule to make sure I attend some more of the events at this theater! 

I used the parking garage next to the theater. I prepaid online for $5. I parked on the second floor and had no issue getting in or out of the parking garage. I can imagine there being an issue if you are parked at a high level.
I've never seen a bad show in this amazing theatre in the round.  There are no bad seats.  This is a real summer treat.  Be warned, tickets have lots extra fees added on.

We recently attended a performance of "An American in Paris" at this great theatre.  Sat in the Orchestra section and seats were very good.  Have seen several live performances at this theatre and have enjoyed them all but this production topped the charts for the best dancing/ballet, great singers and wonderful George & Ira Gershwin tunes.  Unfortunately the show will only be there until early June.  Looking forward to their next season and will definitely attend another show or two then.

Music Circus, now out from under its tent and presented in the wonderful theater-in-the-round Wells Fargo Pavillion, is consistently excellent, and sometimes absolutely amazing.  We have been lucky enough to have enjoyed musicals in New York, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Long Beach and other locales, but have never seen shows as consistently well performed, directed, costumed and staged.  For several years, our season tickets have been directly behind the conductor, so we also enjoy not only the music, but the fine musicians, as well.  Music Circus productions of "Ragtime," "Cats," and "Hunchback of Notre Dame" are seared into my memory.  The use of an extremely talented deaf actor in the latter was a stunning creative decision by which we were deeply touched.  We have been able to see one rehearsal each of the last two years, an educational adventure, for sure.  The director of the play, as well as those of music, sound, lighting, choreography, stage movement (up, down and around on several levels) all give instructions more or less at the same time.  It's incredible to see each person in the production respond only to the appropriate voice.  Within a few days, out of all that cacophony comes a seamless production.  We couldn't recommend anything in Sacramento more highly.  If you are going to be a summer tourist, be sure to see what might be playing.  If you are lucky there might still be tickets available.

name: Old City Cemetery
reviews: Quite a place with it's rich history.  One really needs a guided walk to know all the various stories of this place, especially the hauntings.  One finds a lot of Screech Owls adding to it's mystic.  The cemetery is old and fun to walk through, just calm and peaceful as well.  It's other claim to fame is it's numerous antique roses, many which are only found here and no where else.  Their is various walking tours like halloween, roses and history depending on one's interest.  The rose society offers rose growing tips, rose cuttings for sale and ask for volunteers to do rose pruning.  I'm so glad this place was preserved.
You can schedule a tour with your visit.  Many iconic people are buried at this cemetery .  It's fun to go for Halloween.

A great place to include in a walk through downtown or to walk. Long narrow lanes between monuments dating to the early days of Sacramento. You start out not looking at the names and dates but you can't help noticing and then you start dreaming of the stories buried all around and how they blend together in unseen ways that leave marks on us now. A good place to read poems aloud.

My family and I visited the Old City Cemetery last year on a free-access day, a city-wide Museum day I think it was. We had a fun time exploring (so much bigger than you'd think). We even got to do a little geocaching. Make note of where the bathrooms are!
right off the I80 freeway. Most of the city's historic figures buried here and wonderfully landscaped. Good place to take your dog for a walk as less crowded than the parks.

name: Sacramento Convention Center
reviews: As convention centers go, this one is not large for a major city. However it is smack downtown and conveniently located to gov't offices, over priced hotels, and the capitol of the 6th largest economy in the world. It has a small city feel, but can hold some decent sized conventions. Parking can be challenging after 8 or 9 am when a large convention is in play so arrive early. Services are not huge, limited to a few drink and dining establishments so plan on eating elsewhere if interested in something other than institutional food. Cheers!

Sacramento Convention Center: perfect place for a large crowd. We spent hours visiting the venues and touring the centers. Parking can be difficult at times but usually it flows without too much hassle. Suggest you go early or during the week. Lots of restaurants throughout the venue. Take your time, don’t rush and just have fun!

This was a very nice, well kept, large facility for a conference that I was there attending. I really enjoyed my time there, and everything was kept clean, including the bathrooms. Parking leaves much to be desired though. There is no convention center parking, so you have to park on the street or in paid lots around the area, which can be spendy.

I have only been to the Easy Rider Show here, but it has  been a positive experience every time. If I get a chance to attend something else here that interest me I will. Also there is a lot of parking and cool places to eat nearby.
My husband and I had attended concerts at the Sacramento Convention Center. The staff is very polite and well-mannered.
Great location to hold a convention. Near many hotels and some great restaurants. Currently being remodeled so I am sure it will only get better.
Sacramento Convention Center, and the surrounding area, are not as confusing as may appear from the freeway and surrounding streets.  Well marked with good public access.

I've attended reptile shows, comic-cons, and Lego events here with my family. It's very large, but they make it easy to not get lost. Close to many food choices. I can't compare it to others (except for San Diego), but it's a great venue.

name: California Museum
reviews: If you drive you must find parking in the area. There are several pay-to-park lots and some metered street spaces. Admission is paid in the gift shop. There are 2 floors of exhibits. Part of the second floor is the "California Hall of Fame." One can get a good history of California by visiting the various exhibits.

The Health exhibit, the early California Indian tribes experience, the "RIGHTS" movement, the Newest American project and the beautiful people of the world photos, the wonderful Women's exhibits, the famous people exhibit who contributed to California's growth and diversity along with the amazing Encina Preparatory High School story and the new Unity Center "everyone has a voice"... An important place to visit. An educational visual odyssey.
Amazing California history with fun interactive exhibits; and exciting and cool CA Hall of Fame exhibition!
The Gold Mountain exhibit was excellent, providing a timeline of the history of Chinese in America since the Gold Rush. Interactive displays and exhibits tell the story.

I actually visited in June 2018, however due to travelling all over the world for the last 18 months, I am just in the process of writing all the reviews.  It’s not a massive museum; it took me about 90 minutes to see everything.  In additional to information about California becoming the 31st state and the discovery of gold, the museum also includes an interesting exhibit about the Japanese Americans who were imprisoned during WW2 after the bombings of Pearl Harbour; the exhibit includes artefacts and personal stories.  The museum also includes a few smaller exhibits which were interesting to walk through.

If you drive you must find parking in the area. There are several pay-to-park lots and some metered street spaces. Admission is paid in the gift shop. There are 2 floors of exhibits. Part of the second floor is the "California Hall of Fame." One can get a good history of California by visiting the various exhibits.

The lovely friendly ticket person told us immediately that the most popular attraction is the one room on Japanese internment. Upon walking through the museum it clear why: it is the only diorama of artifacts in the entire museum not counting the completely random vintage "diner" booths at the bottom of the back stairs. There is no diorama on Missions, the gold rush, the movie industry... no artifacts, no displays, nothing on things you would consider historic to California. What there is are a a lot of pictures of individuals and a lot of text (such as Barbara Streisand: You could be forgiven for wondering what this Brooklyn girl has to do with California history). Its like a 3D Wikipedia page... read it at home and save $9 cause other than pictures, which you can see on line, there are no displays.
I really enjoyed the museum! The staff was very helpful with getting our city passes for us :) which is a great deal.

name: Wells Fargo Museum
reviews: This is a small museum in Old Town area of Sacramento, located quite closed to the Railroad museum and the Old Sacramento waterfront. The history of Wells Fargo is closely linked with the Gold Rush in California in mid nineteenth century and this museum does a commendable job of concisely chronicling that. Believe me, the museum is very small indeed. If you are really curious about reading all the exhibits in detail, you might take 15 minutes inside but in most cases you'll be in and out in 5 minutes or so! They had a working telegraph which uses the Morse code and it is connected real time with some other Well Fargo museums scattered at multiple cities across US, that was a fun exhibit. The exhibits were mostly about the history of Wells Fargo and Pony Express, the first mail delivery systems connecting the West with cities east of the Mississippi. The entry is free.
I found this museum very interesting, especially the connection to Stage Coach robber Black Bart. I recommend researching this robber and his intense dislike of Wells Fargo!

Small museum but packs a big punch.  It has memorabilia of the gold rush, early banking history, the pony express and the telegraph.  Even a corner is dedicated to the journalist Mark Twain.
The stair steps outside in the front is the original steps to the state Supreme Court.  And it's all free so it doesn't get better than that.
It's a very small museum and a quick stop.  Still, they have a lot of interesting artifacts from the Gold Rush days, and it was educational to learn the history of Wells Fargo.

Although the museum is small, there's a museum who's able to tell you a lot about the history of Wells Fargo and related stories during the time they first built it. Great to add this to your browsing route.
My partner is a teller at a Wells Fargo Bank and this museum was so cool and interesting! We had a blast and I really enjoyed the fact there was an Wells Fargo ATM machine in the museum!

Tiny but nice. What is special is that this is where Wells Fargo stood over 150 years ago.  ATM is there, convenient for getting cash, but this is a mini museum, not a service bank. Nice staff. My favorite atm! I just love to walk in here.

name: Arden Fair
reviews: Wow, so much has changed at the Arden Fair Mall. Beautiful new designs, lovely areas to shop, I’m very impressed! Great places to dine, too. Macy’s is one of the best. Don’t forget the See’s Candy. Lots of good options here and the restrooms are very clean. Can’t wait to return for more shopping fun at Arden Fair!!

This mall is just what you expect, with a paradise of stores. It is 2 floors, with elevator, and the food court is perfect! Some stores, like LIDS, offer sports jerseys and you can CUSTOMIZE them yourself! Would definitely come back to Sac and visit this mall
This is a nice mall with a good selection of stores. It has 2 stories and seems spacious compared to other malls I've been too. when we went it was beautifully decorated for Christmas.

This mall and the area have long been known as a ghetto. 

One would think that it's just males causing the problems but the disappointing reality is this place and area had had long term problems with female gangs and female hate groups.

And now the media has reported that the Sacramento region, from Elk Grove to Roseville and inland are amongst the worst place in the country for singles.

It's sad because California just had one of the most powerful governors but the hate groups remain.

Don't be surprised if your identity becomes known all over the area before you realize it. 
And this area contribute to the next generation of hate.

While it is very convenient to get here as you can literally see the BUS 80 freeway from the mall parking can be difficult at times - especially during the holiday season. The mall is probably the oldest in Sacramento but has been remodeled.  There are many great restaurants but better to go on a weekday. There are also movie theaters so you can watch, shop and eat all at one place.

First opened in 1957, the Arden Fair mall has woven its way into the cultural and economic fabric of Sacramento. In its 60+ year history this mall, much like the community that surrounds it, has seen both “boom” and “bust” periods. And like most malls in the country, it seems to me like Arden Fair is experiencing a moderate and prolonged “bust” period thanks to the growing proliferation of online shopping. That’s not to say the mall is barren – because it isn’t; however, I’m positive its seen happier times, traffic-wise.

In any event, despite being over 60 years old, Arden Fair is nicely maintained. In fact, it looks far newer than many malls half its age, so many a kudo should be given to management for keeping this mall looking relatively fresh and modern in comparison to its counterparts elsewhere in the country. And, despite the major increase in online shopping over, say, the last decade, this mall has been able to hold onto and/or bring in new tenants on a regular basis. Anchor tenants include: Sears (here since DAY 1), JC Penny, Macy’s and Nordstrom. Beyond the anchor stores, Arden Fair has over 160 stores and restaurants, including: American Eagle, Apple, Banana Republic, Bath & Body Works, BJ’s, Box Lunch, Cinnabon, Coach, Disney, Forever 21, GAP, Hot Topic, Journeys, Panda Express, Spencer, amongst many others. In short, there’s something in Arden Fair for everybody young and old.

It had been a good six years since I’d last patronized Arden Fair, so this was a good mini sort of nostalgia trip for me. In both cases, though, my visit was done more as a way to kill time rather than actively seeking out a shopping mall. The one difference between 2012 and the current day, however? I was actually looking forward to visiting Sears since this large retailer shuttered all of its doors in Canada in 2017. It’s funny how the mind works sometimes. All throughout my life, I never really cared much about Sears – or at least didn’t notice its value – but once it disappeared from the Canadian landscape, I rather missed it. Ironically, I didn’t end up buying anything at the Arden Fair Sears, but at least I got a nice photo of the SEARS signage . . . it’s the little things ;)

While I wouldn’t go quite so far as “Visit Sacramento” and declare Arden Fair Mall a “jewel among the beautiful landscape of Northern California,” I will nevertheless concede that it is a nice mall to visit, both structurally and in terms of the variety of stores. However, unless you’re really big on shopping, I wouldn’t necessarily go out of my way to come here and instead would only use it as a time killer of sorts.​

Wow, so much has changed at the Arden Fair Mall. Beautiful new designs, lovely areas to shop, I’m very impressed! Great places to dine, too. Macy’s is one of the best. Don’t forget the See’s Candy. Lots of good options here and the restrooms are very clean. Can’t wait to return for more shopping fun at Arden Fair!!

This mall is just what you expect, with a paradise of stores. It is 2 floors, with elevator, and the food court is perfect! Some stores, like LIDS, offer sports jerseys and you can CUSTOMIZE them yourself! Would definitely come back to Sac and visit this mall
